title: The Morning Risk Report: Commerce Dept. Sends Strong Message in ZTE Ban - Risk & Compliance Journal. - WSJ
text:

Visitors pass ZTE booth at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona in February. REUTERS/Sergio Perez/File Photo Good morning. The export ban imposed by the U.S. on China-based telecommunications company ZTE Corp. should serve as a lesson to other businesses about what happens when a company lies to the U.S. government.
The U.S. Commerce Department stung ZTE with a seven-year ban this week after it accused the company of making false statements since striking a $1.19 billion settlement last year over export-controls and sanctions violations. “Law enforcement hates nothing more than being lied to,” Douglas Jacobson, a partner at the international trade-focused firm Jacobson Burton Kelley PLLC, told Risk & Compliance Journal’s Samuel Rubenfeld . The firm represents companies that import products from, and export components to, ZTE.
Companies that ignore U.S. law put their access to U.S. technology and markets at risk, said Daniel Glaser, principal at the Financial Integrity Network, a consultancy that advises governments and companies on illicit finance threats. “Firms facing enforcement actions need to be fully forthcoming with U.S. officials and follow through on their commitments to the U.S. government, both in letter and spirit,” said Mr. Glaser.
ZTE retained and paid full bonuses to employees it was supposed to discipline for the violations; the government only learned about it after the Commerce Department requested documents verifying the action, the U.S. alleged.
The Chinese company halted trading on Tuesday following the allegations. It said in a brief statement it “is assessing the full range of potential implications” of the U.S. order and is communicating with relevant parties over how to respond. ZTE relies on U.S. components for its products.
ZTE established a crisis-management team, the company’s chairman said in a memo seen by the South China Morning Post. In it, he appealed for calm from the company’s 80,000 workers. “The company is actively communicating and giving its all to resolve this crisis,” said Chairman Yin Yimin in the memo.
The U.S. allegations sent the stock prices of optical-component firms sliding and placed American companies in the crossfire .
EXCLUSIVE ON RISK AND COMPLIANCE JOURNAL 
U.S. bars second Albanian official. The State Department blocked a former Albanian member of parliament from coming into the U.S., making him the second official from that country to be denied access under an anti-corruption law this year.
COMPLIANCE 
Germans push for a break on sanctions. German leaders want the U.S. to exempt their country’s companies from new sanctions on Russia. In a visit to Washington this week, Germany’s finance minister will push for special treatment and Chancellor Angela Merkel plans to raise the issue with President Donald Trump this month. Many German firms do substantial business in Russia, the WSJ reports.
A worker walks in front of pipes at the Nord Stream 2 facility in Sassnitz, Germany. Utility Uniper SE, a partner in the pipeline being built to connect Russia and Europe, says it is worried about U.S. sanctions on Russia. PHOTO: CARSTEN KOALL/GETTY IMAGES Republicans prepare to kill auto-loan rule. Republicans in Congress moved to undo a regulation aimed at racial discrimination for auto loans, the WSJ reports. The Senate on Tuesday voted to proceed with legislation to overturn 2013 guidance on lending at auto dealerships. A final vote is expected Wednesday, and the House is expected to approve its version of the legislation shortly thereafter.
U.S. proposes quota changes on drugs. The Trump administration proposed changing federal rules to say that officials must consider how badly a drug is being abused in setting quotas for the production of the medication. Attorney General Jeff Sessions said the action would help address the nation’s opioid problem, the WSJ reports.
New York pushes crypto exchanges on transparency. New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman is pressing cryptocurrency exchanges to increase transparency. Mr. Schneiderman’s office’s on Tuesday requested information from 13 exchanges specializing in cryptocurrencies, saying investors often lack facts needed to protect themselves, the WSJ reports.
SoftBank corrects tax filings. SoftBank Group Corp. , the operator of the world’s largest technology fund, said it corrected four years of tax filings after Japanese authorities uncovered ¥93.9 billion (about $875 million) worth of unreported earnings at offshore subsidiaries, the WSJ reports.
DATA SECURITY 
Facebook offers preview on privacy makeover. Facebook this week will start asking European users for permission to use their data for features like facial recognition and some forms of targeted advertising, the WSJ reports. Facebook said it would allow users in the rest of the world to review those details in coming months. The firm is seeking to allay concerns over how it handles personal information.
REPUTATION 
Southwest starts accident probe. Southwest Airlines said it is accelerating inspections of some engines following a failure on a flight between New York and Dallas. The engine failure forced an emergency landing and caused the first fatality in an accident on a U.S. airline since 2009, the WSJ reports.
Starbucks plans antibias training. Starbucks will close thousands of stores on a May afternoon to conduct antibias employee education. A video posted online this past weekend showed police handcuffing two black men at a Starbucks in Philadelphia, while customers told police the men weren’t doing anything wrong and asked why they were being arrested. The coffee chain’s CEO has apologized for the incident, the WSJ reports.
RISK 
Seoul sees path for formal end to Korean War. A South Korean official said Seoul could push for a more permanent peace agreement on the Korean Peninsula to replace the armistice that ended the Korean War. The news comes as the North and South formalize the agenda for a meeting between their leaders this month, the WSJ reports.
Pompeo met with Kim Jong Un. President Donald Trump sent Central Intelligence Agency Director Mike Pompeo to meet North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Pyongyang over Easter. Mr. Pompeo, tapped by Mr. Trump to be secretary of state, met with Mr. Kim to discuss a summit between the leaders of the two countries aimed at ending North Korea’s nuclear-weapons program, the WSJ reports.
Bump-stock firm to stop taking orders. Bump-stock maker Slide Fire will stop taking orders for the device that makes semiautomatic rifles shoot like rapid-fire machine guns and shut down its website on May 20, the company said. The federal government is moving ahead with plans for a bump-stock ban, which could take effect later this year, the WSJ reports.
In February, President Donald Trump directed the Justice Department to ban bump stocks. PHOTO: GEORGE FREY/GETTY IMAGES OPERATIONS 
Computer trouble hits the IRS. The Internal Revenue Service issued a one-day, penalty-free extension for tax filers after suffering an all-day computer breakdown on Tuesday that prevented taxpayers from filing returns electronically on the day 2017 payments were due, the WSJ reports. The IRS blamed the problem on a hardware error.
JetBlue flight attendants to unionize. Flight attendants for New York-based carrier JetBlue Airways Corp. have voted to join the Transport Workers Union of America. The vote affects roughly 5,000 staff. The airline’s pilots joined the Air Line Pilots Association in 2014, the WSJ reports.
STRATEGY 
Total makes electricity deal. Total said it would pay €1.4 billion ($1.73 billion) for a majority stake in electricity provider Direct Energie , the latest step in the company’s strategy to become a power player. Total is among the most aggressive in a small group of big oil-and-gas companies that are snapping up traditional utilities and renewable-energy firms, the WSJ reports.
